tn.text: This means "Yahweh, the God he worshiped." The word "his" does not mean that Jonah owned God.
"Jonah said"

tn.ref: I called out to Yahweh about my distress
tn.text: "I prayed to Yahweh about my great trouble." Even though Jonah was praying to Yahweh, he used Yahweh's name here and not "you." AT: "Yahweh, I called out to you about my distress"
"Yahweh responded to me" or "he helped me"

"from the center of Sheol" or "from the deep part of Sheol." Possible meanings are 1) Jonah was speaking as being in the belly of the whale was being in Sheol or 2) Jonah believed that he was about to die and go to Sheol or 3) He spoke as if he already had died and gone there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a continuation of Jonah's prayer that started in [[:en:bible:notes:jon:02:01|2:2]]. In verse 4 Jonah spoke of something he had prayed before this prayer.

tn.ref: into the depths, into the heart of the seas
tn.text: This speaks of the vastness of the ocean Jonah was in. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: into the heart of the seas
tn.text: "to the bottom of the sea"
"the sea water closed in around me"
These are disturbances on the surface of the ocean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "You have driven me away" or "You have sent me away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"from you." When Jonah said "your eyes" he was speaking about Yahweh in his entirety. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: yet I will again look toward your holy temple
tn.text: Jonah has hope that, in spite of all he is going through, he will see the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a continuation of Jonah's prayer that started in [[:en:bible:notes:jon:02:01|2:2]].
"The waters" refers to the sea.
Some versions understand the Hebrew word in this expression to mean "my life." In that interpretation, the waters were about to take away Jonah's life.

tn.ref: the deep was all around me
tn.text: "the deep water was all around me"
"grass that grows in the sea"

tn.ref: the earth with its bars closed upon me forever
tn.text: Jonah used a metaphor to compare the earth to a prison. AT: "the earth was like a prison that was about to lock me in forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Yet you brought up my life from the pit
tn.text: Jonah speaks of the place of the dead as if it were a pit. AT: "But you saved my life from the place of the dead" or "But you saved me from the place where the dead people are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
In some languages, it may be more natural to put this at the beginning of the sentence or next to the word "you."
This is a continuation of Jonah's prayer that started in [[:en:bible:notes:jon:02:01|2:2]].
Since Jonah was praying to Yahweh, it might be more clear in some languages to say "I thought about you, Yahweh" or "Yahweh, I thought about you." (UDB)

tn.ref: then my prayer came to you, to your holy temple
tn.text: Jonah speaks as if his prayers could travel to God and his temple. AT: "then you in your holy temple heard my prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Those who pay attention to useless gods
tn.text: "People who pay attention to useless gods"
"are rejecting you, who would be faithful to them"
This is a continuation of Jonah's prayer that started in [[:en:bible:notes:jon:02:01|2:2]].
This expression in English shows that there is a contrast between the people Jonah had just spoken about and himself. They paid attention to useless gods, but he would worship Yahweh. AT: "But I"

tn.ref: I will sacrifice to you with a voice of thanksgiving
tn.text: This means that Jonah would thank God while he offered a sacrifice to him. It is not clear whether Jonah planned to thank God by singing or shouting joyfully.
This can be reworded so that the abstract noun "salvation" is expressed as the verb "save." "Yahweh is the one who saves people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"upon the ground" or "onto the shore"
